9:I[37277,["/_next/static/chunks/780ed9f12bd597e3.js","/_next/static/chunks/93fb432403aebbdd.js","/_next/static/chunks/6ed45c29e6db9297.js","/_next/static/chunks/ca6e69eece0158a1.js","/_next/static/chunks/c6ed05d45582b587.js"],"Separator"]

12:"$Sreact.suspense"
2:T1022,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Recipe","name":"Argentine Empanadas","description":"The iconic Argentine hand pie, baked to golden perfection with a savory beef filling spiced with cumin, paprika, and green olives. The Salteñas style from northern Argentina is the most beloved variation nationwide.","image":"https://expatsargentina.com/images/recipes/empanadas.webp","author":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Expats Argentina"},"datePublished":"2025-01-01","prepTime":"PT45M","cookTime":"PT25M","totalTime":"PT70M","recipeYield":"12 servings","recipeCategory":"appetizer","recipeCuisine":"Argentine","keywords":"argentine empanadas recipe, empanadas salteñas, authentic empanadas, beef empanadas, how to make empanadas","nutrition":{"@type":"NutritionInformation","calories":"280 calories","proteinContent":"12g","carbohydrateContent":"32g","fatContent":"14g"},"recipeIngredient":["For the dough: 3 cups (450g) all-purpose flour","For the dough: 1/2 cup (120ml) warm water","For the dough: 1/4 cup (60ml) melted beef fat or lard","For the dough: 1 tsp salt","For the dough: 1 egg (for dough)","For the dough: 1 egg (for egg wash)","For the filling (picadillo): 500g (1 lb) ground beef (20% fat)","For the filling (picadillo): 2 medium onions, finely diced","For the filling (picadillo): 2 cloves garlic, minced","For the filling (picadillo): 1 red bell pepper, diced","For the filling (picadillo): 2 hard-boiled eggs, chopped","For the filling (picadillo): 1/2 cup green olives, chopped","For the filling (picadillo): 2 tbsp raisins (optional)","For the filling (picadillo): 2 tsp ground cumin","For the filling (picadillo): 2 tsp sweet paprika (pimentón dulce)","For the filling (picadillo): 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes (ají molido)","For the filling (picadillo): Salt and black pepper to taste","For the filling (picadillo): 3 tbsp beef fat or oil for cooking"],"recipeInstructions":[{"@type":"HowToStep","position":1,"text":"Make the dough: Mix flour and salt in a large bowl. Create a well and add egg, melted fat, and warm water. Mix until a shaggy dough forms, then knead for 8-10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Wrap in plastic and rest at room temperature for 30 minutes."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":2,"text":"Prepare the filling: Heat beef fat in a large skillet over medium heat. Add onions and cook until soft and translucent (8-10 minutes). Add garlic and red pepper, cook 2 more minutes."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":3,"text":"Add ground beef, breaking it up with a spoon. Cook until browned but not fully cooked through—about 5 minutes. The beef will finish cooking in the oven."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":4,"text":"Season with cumin, paprika, red pepper flakes, salt, and black pepper. The filling should taste slightly overseasoned. Remove from heat and let cool completely."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":5,"text":"Once cooled, fold in chopped hard-boiled eggs, green olives, and raisins (if using). The filling must be cold before assembling to prevent soggy dough."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":6,"text":"Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Divide dough into 12 equal pieces and roll into balls. Cover with a damp cloth."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":7,"text":"Roll each ball into a 6-inch (15cm) circle about 1/8-inch thick. Use a small plate as a template for perfect circles if needed."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":8,"text":"Place 2-3 tablespoons of filling in the center of each circle. Resist overfilling—it will tear the dough."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":9,"text":"Fold dough in half over filling to create a half-moon. Press edges firmly to seal."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":10,"text":"Create the repulgue (traditional crimp): Starting at one end, fold the edge over itself in small sections, creating a rope-like pattern. This seals the empanada and looks beautiful."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":11,"text":"Place empanadas on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Brush with egg wash for a golden finish."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":12,"text":"Bake for 20-25 minutes until deep golden brown. Serve hot with chimichurri on the side."}]}0:{"buildId":"XJ7f5RvYDcX4yjbAXmNYG","rsc":["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"min-h-screen bg-gradient-to-b from-orange-50 to-white","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$2"}}],"$L3","$L4","$L5","$L6"]}],null,"$L7"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
3:["$","div",null,{"className":"border-b bg-white/80 backdrop-blur-sm sticky top-0 z-40 print:hidden","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-5xl mx-auto px-4 py-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-center justify-between","children":["$","$L8",null,{"href":"/food/recipes","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-arrow-left w-4 h-4","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1l729n",{"d":"m12 19-7-7 7-7"}],["$","path","x3x0zl",{"d":"M19 12H5"}],"$undefined"]}],"All Recipes"],"data-slot":"button","data-variant":"ghost","data-size":"sm","className":"inline-flex items-center justify-center whitespace-nowrap text-sm font-medium transition-all disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:opacity-50 [&_svg]:pointer-events-none [&_svg:not([class*='size-'])]:size-4 shrink-0 [&_svg]:shrink-0 outline-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive hover:bg-accent hover:text-accent-foreground dark:hover:bg-accent/50 h-8 rounded-md px-3 has-[>svg]:px-2.5 gap-2","ref":null}]}]}]}]

This seals the empanada and looks beautiful."}]]}]

Don't use oil."}]]}],["$","li","1",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Empanada dough is different from pie crust—it needs to be elastic to fold without cracking. Don't skip the kneading."}]]}],["$","li","2",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"In Argentina, empanadas are identified by their repulgue pattern: carne (meat) has the rope crimp, jamón y queso has a fork-pressed edge."}]]}],["$","li","3",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"For spicy empanadas (carne picante), add more red pepper flakes or a diced fresh chili."}]]}],["$","li","4",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"The filling should be room temperature or cold when assembling. Hot filling will make the dough soggy and difficult to seal."}]]}],["$","li","5",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Buy pre-made tapas de empanada (empanada discs) at Argentine supermarkets if you're short on time—they're surprisingly good."}]]}]]}]}]]}]
22:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","id":"history","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-history w-5 h-5 text-orange-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1357e3",{"d":"M3 12a9 9 0 1 0 9-9 9.75 9.75 0 0 0-6.74 2.74L3 8"}],["$","path","1xhq8a",{"d":"M3 3v5h5"}],["$","path","1fdv2h",{"d":"M12 7v5l4 2"}],"$undefined"]}],"The Story Behind the Dish"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700 leading-relaxed","children":"Empanadas arrived in Argentina with Spanish colonists but evolved into a distinctly Argentine tradition. The Salteñas variety, named after the city of Salta, are known for their distinctive crimped edge (repulgue) and slightly spicy meat filling. Each Argentine province claims its own style—Tucumanas are juicier, Cordobesas are sweeter with raisins, and Salteñas strike the perfect balance."}]}]]}]
23:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6 pb-3","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Storage & Leftovers"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-0","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Refrigerate cooked empanadas for up to 3 days. Freeze unbaked empanadas for up to 3 months—bake from frozen, adding 5-7 minutes. Reheat baked empanadas in a 350°F (180°C) oven for 10 minutes to restore crispness."}]}]]}]
